hobby.message: Freestyle FPV — your kind of silence, right?
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: City's fine, as much as it can be lately.
I mess around with drones, off the clock.
Had some weird interruptions last weekend out flying.
Nothing you put in the air goes unnoticed anymore.
Hanging in there, thanks.
I fly FPV drones, mostly abandoned zones to keep clear.
Last run got cut short—too many gawkers, never seen them before.
People seemed anxious. Flare-ups everywhere after the BCI mess.
Sticking to less-tracked spots for now.
Doing alright, things are tense since Halden’s story broke.
My escape’s drone flying—FPV, real-time acrobatics through old rail zones.
Usually, it's empty, just a few pilots. This week felt… watched.
Some tried asking for tech favors, wristband stuff.
Always made me nervous—never happened before.
Left early, just wasn’t worth the headache.
Yeah, city’s rougher than usual lately, propaganda everywhere.
I fly freestyle drones, keeps my mind clear—old industrial zones mostly.
Last Sunday, crowd was there, arguing over Halden and the BCI collapse.
Signals were glitchy, safety beacons down. Saw some tech jamming.
A guy asked me to blackout a tracker—never been cornered like that before.
My hands wouldn’t stop shaking all afternoon.
It’s not the peaceful escape it used to be.
Honestly, the city itself feels like a drone—controlled, but off-balance since Halden’s death.
FPV drone flying’s been my anchor since my brother vanished—it’s the only quiet I get.
Used to love getting lost in the rail yards’ dead zones, tuning PID loops, timing risky passes.
Now, even out there, crowds form arguing over fake Council news.
Signals jammed, trackers unreliable—people asked me how to vanish.
That’s when I knew: system’s falling apart if everyone wants out.
I left early, couldn’t shake the sense of surveillance closing in.
Wish I could trust the sky again, but not right now.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still flying.
Barely found a clear signal out in Sector 17.
People everywhere arguing about Halden and the Council.
Airspace isn’t what it was last month.
BCI disruptions mess up beacons now.
Yeah, still my go-to escape.
Tried the depot last weekend—signal lag’s getting worse.
Crowds just standing around, watching propaganda feeds.
Had to cut the flight short, watched by strangers.
New people asked weird questions about wristbands.
Feels riskier to fly now.
Yep, FPV keeps my mind straight.
Depot runs are harder—old city jams more since the BCI crash.
Missed a perfect gap when beacons failed mid-flight.
Some hobbyists seem nervous, like everyone’s on edge.
Too many bystanders ranting Halden conspiracy theories.
One tried trading me cash for wristband hacks.
Not what it used to be.
Yeah, flying’s still the best way to zone out.
Last session, Sector 17 was packed—arguments about the BCI everywhere.
Halden’s death broke things: GPS glitching, safety beacons unreliable.
Some guy begged me to block his band—never seen that before.
I just wanted a clean loop, not paranoia.
Council’s chaos even infects the off-grid spots now.
Makes me miss the silence up there.
Still, can’t give it up.
Yeah, always therapy—unless the city decides otherwise.
Sunday, flew the depot—felt off: too many faces watching feeds.
BCI chaos means random gaps, even old beacons going dead midflight.
Someone recognized my sleeve patch, got pushy about ghosting his band.
Used to be honesty among us pilots—now everyone’s scared of the Council or chasing fixes.
I nearly crashed—a signal jam, hands shaking for the first time in years.
Strange to see my secret spot turned panicked, people whispering Halden theories.
Even the air feels less free since the Directorate’s counter-narratives.
Guess flying’s no longer outside the system, but I can’t quit.
